steps.new_information: No clinical information or images provided yet; initiating diagnostic evaluation for dermatologic lesions.
current_uncertainties: Basal cell carcinoma: common skin cancer on sun-exposed areas, often pearly papule with telangiectasia
Squamous cell carcinoma: can present as scaly/ulcerated lesion, may be indurated and prone to bleeding
Melanoma: pigmented, asymmetric lesion with irregular borders and color variegation, high-risk if changing
Seborrheic keratosis (benign): common ‘‘stuck-on’’ waxy lesion that can mimic malignancies but usually non-tender and stable

steps.new_information: Vital signs: Temperature 36.8°C, Blood Pressure 130/85 mmHg, Heart Rate 82 bpm, Respiratory Rate 14/min — within normal limits, no fever or hemodynamic instability.
current_uncertainties: Basal cell carcinoma: common cutaneous malignancy, often a pearly papule with telangiectasia and slow growth
consider if lesion is nodular or ulcerated
Squamous cell carcinoma: can present as scaly, erythematous plaque or ulcerated lesion that may bleed and grow more rapidly, especially on sun-exposed areas
Melanoma: pigmented lesion with asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation and change over time — high oncologic concern if history of change
Benign lesion (seborrheic keratosis/dermatofibroma): can mimic malignant lesions but usually stable, “stuck-on” appearance or firm papule without rapid change.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: What is your age and sex, and when did you first notice the skin lesion? Has it changed in size, shape, or color, or bled/ulcerated, or become painful or itchy?

steps.new_information: 62-year-old man; red, crusty spots on penis and left middle finger first noticed four months ago (prior to arrival in US); lesions have increased slightly in size and crustiness; no bleeding, ulceration, pain, or pruritus.
current_uncertainties: Invasive squamous cell carcinoma (penile SCC/finger SCC): older age and progressive crusting lesion on penis and finger raise concern for SCC
Bowen disease (SCC in situ): chronic scaly/crusty lesions on genitalia in older patients can represent in situ disease
Fixed drug eruption: classically causes well-demarcated erythematous/crusty lesions on genitalia and could affect multiple sites but usually recurrent after drug exposure
HPV-related lesion/Bowenoid papulosis: HPV-associated lesions can affect the penis and may present as multiple papules/plaques though typically in younger patients.
steps.next_step_action: ASK PATIENT: Have you had any recent new sexual partners or known sexually transmitted infections, do you have any history of HIV or other immunosuppression, and have you started any new medications in the past year?

steps.new_information: 62-year-old man with red, crusty spots on penis and left middle finger for ~4 months; lesions have gradually enlarged and become crustier but are non-bleeding, non-ulcerated, non-painful, non-pruritic. Prior treatments for syphilis and eczema in Africa were ineffective. No history of HIV or immunosuppression, no new medications, monogamous relationship.
current_uncertainties: Erythroplasia of Queyrat (penile Bowen disease/SCC in situ): chronic erythematous crusty penile lesion in older male is classic for carcinoma in situ
Squamous cell carcinoma (invasive): persistent crusted lesions on penis and finger could represent invasive SCC, especially given age and chronicity
Cutaneous leishmaniasis: travel history to Africa and chronic painless crusted lesions that failed routine treatments fit this infection
Atypical mycobacterial or chronic deep fungal infection: chronic crusted lesions refractory to standard therapy could reflect atypical mycobacterial (e.g., M. marinum/africanum) or fungal infection.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Focused dermatologic exam of lesions (genital and left hand) including dermoscopy and palpation of regional lymph nodes

steps.new_information: Erythematous plaques with areas of crusting, oozing, and irregular borders on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger; lesions are firm, non-tender, without warmth; no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.
current_uncertainties: Bowen disease (squamous cell carcinoma in situ): erythematous crusted plaque on genitalia classically presents this way and may involve penile skin
Invasive squamous cell carcinoma: firm, crusting lesion on penis/finger could represent invasive SCC though no nodal spread yet
Extramammary Paget disease: can present as chronic erythematous, crusted genital plaque and may mimic eczema
Chronic inflammatory or infectious dermatitis (eczema, tinea, treated syphilis): prior treatments failed and firmness/irregular borders make these less likely but not excluded.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Punch biopsy of the penile lesion and left middle finger lesion for histopathology and HPV testing

steps.new_information: Biopsy from penile and left middle finger lesions shows cells with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitotic figures within follicle-bearing epithelium; HPV testing returned normal/negative.
current_uncertainties: Squamous cell carcinoma (invasive or in situ/Bowen disease): epithelial atypia, mitoses, and multinucleation consistent with SCC/Bowen
Keratoacanthoma or crateriform SCC variant: can show rapid growth and atypical squamous proliferation but typically has characteristic architecture
Viral wart with viral cytopathic effect (e.g., HPV): multinucleation can occur but HPV testing is negative making this less likely
Metastatic or multifocal cutaneous malignancy (e.g., metastatic SCC): presence of similar lesions at distant sites raises possibility of multifocal primary SCC vs metastasis.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Additional histopathology — deeper sectioning and immunohistochemistry including p16, cytokeratin AE1/AE3, and Ki-67 to evaluate for HPV-related markers, squamous differentiation, and proliferation, and report depth of invasion and margin status

steps.new_information: Deeper histopathology and immunohistochemistry (p16, cytokeratin AE1/AE3, Ki-67) returned 'NORMAL READINGS'.
current_uncertainties: Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (Bowen disease/erythroplasia of Queyrat): biopsy shows marked squamous atypia, multinucleation, and mitoses within follicle-bearing epithelium consistent with SCC in situ
Invasive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma: firm, crusted lesions on penis and finger and cellular atypia raise concern for invasion—depth not documented
Extramammary Paget disease: erythematous crusted genital lesion could represent Paget's and would require CK7/CEA to exclude though current histology favors squamous differentiation
Keratoacanthoma/reactive epithelial atypia: can mimic SCC histologically but multifocality, persistence, and atypical mitoses make benign mimic less likely.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Additional immunohistochemistry panel (p63, CK5/6, CK7, EMA, CEA, S100) and explicit reporting of depth of invasion and margin status from re-sectioned/deeper levels.

steps.new_information: Additional immunohistochemistry panel (p63, CK5/6, CK7, EMA, CEA, S100) and explicit reporting of deeper-level sections (depth of invasion and margin status) returned normal/negative readings.
current_uncertainties: Bowen disease (squamous cell carcinoma in situ): initial biopsy showed nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitoses consistent with SCC in situ, but subsequent negative squamous markers and no invasion on deeper sections make this uncertain
Invasive squamous cell carcinoma: high mitotic activity raises concern for invasive SCC that could be missed on sampling despite negative deeper sections
Extramammary Paget disease: clinical site (penile) and crusting/oozing could represent EMPD, but CK7/CEA/EMA were negative, leaving possible sampling or atypical staining as uncertainties

Reactive/benign mimicker (pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia or chronic dermatitis) or pagetoid melanoma: atypical histology might represent reactive hyperplasia or a melanoma variant despite negative S100—sampling/IHC limitations remain.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Excisional biopsy of the penile lesion and left middle finger lesion with deeper/full-thickness sections and an extended immunohistochemistry panel (p40, p63, CK5/6, CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15, SOX10, Melan-A, S100, CD3, CD4) plus HPV PCR; explicitly report depth of invasion and margin status.

steps.new_information: Excisional biopsies of the penile and left middle finger lesions with extended immunohistochemistry panel (p40, p63, CK5/6, CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15, SOX10, Melan-A, S100, CD3, CD4) and HPV PCR returned 'NORMAL READINGS'.
current_uncertainties: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease): initial biopsy showed nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitoses consistent with squamous dysplasia/CIS, but subsequent extended IHC/excision reported normal — could be sampling/interpretation discrepancy
Extramammary Paget disease: clinical presentation on genitalia can mimic eczema/erythroplasia and present with pagetoid cells, but glandular markers (CK7, CEA, GCDFP-15) were negative
Melanoma (pagetoid/melanoma in situ): can present as erythematous crusted plaque and mimic other intraepithelial processes, but melanocytic markers (S100, Melan-A, SOX10) were negative

Chronic inflammatory/infectious dermatitis (e.g., chronic eczema, tinea, cutaneous infection): fits chronic crusting nature and lack of systemic spread, but histologic atypia on initial biopsy argues against purely inflammatory process.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Expert dermatopathology review of all original biopsy and excision slides at a tertiary pathology center with repeat HPV testing (PCR and in-situ hybridization) and explicit, itemized report of depth of invasion, margin status, and any residual intraepidermal/invasive disease.

steps.new_information: Expert dermatopathology review of all original biopsy and excision slides with repeat HPV testing (PCR and ISH) returned normal readings with no residual intraepidermal or invasive disease reported.
current_uncertainties: Bowen disease / squamous cell carcinoma in situ: initial biopsy showed atypical keratinocytes, mitoses, and multinucleation consistent with squamous neoplasia but later reviews were normal suggesting sampling variability or misinterpretation
Chronic dermatitis / eczema with reactive atypia: clinical crusty erythematous plaques and prior eczema history could explain reactive epidermal changes and negative HPV/IHC

Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia or other inflammatory/reactive epidermal hyperplasia: can mimic carcinoma histologically and may be benign, consistent with multiple normal expert reviews and negative HPV testing.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Repeat punch biopsy of both lesions for fungal and mycobacterial cultures, PAS/GMS and AFB stains, and PCR for Leishmania, with repeat histopathology and explicit reporting of depth of invasion and margin status

steps.new_information: Repeat punch biopsies including fungal/mycobacterial cultures, PAS/GMS and AFB stains, and PCR for Leishmania returned normal/negative results with no organisms identified and histopathology again non-diagnostic for invasion.
current_uncertainties: Bowen disease (squamous cell carcinoma in situ): clinical appearance (erythematous crusted plaque) and earlier histology showing keratinocytic atypia and increased mitoses support this, but multiple deeper sections and IHC failed to confirm invasion
Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia/reactive atypia: chronic inflammation or trauma can produce marked atypia that mimics malignancy and infectious studies are negative, making this plausible
Extramammary Paget disease or adenocarcinoma in epidermis: lesion location and crusting could fit, but CK7/CEA/GCDFP-15 were negative arguing against Paget

Atypical adnexal carcinoma or an uncommon non-HPV-associated cutaneous malignancy: histologic atypia confined to follicle-bearing epithelium and persistent lesion despite negative routine workup make a rare adnexal carcinoma or molecularly-driven neoplasm possible.
steps.next_step_action: REQUEST TEST: Targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) panel of archived lesion tissue for oncogenic mutations and copy number alterations

steps.reason_ready: The initial diagnostic biopsy demonstrated dysplastic keratinocytes with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitotic figures within epidermal/follicle-bearing epithelium—findings most consistent with squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). Extensive follow-up testing (deeper sections, wide IHC panels including squamous markers, expert dermatopathology review, repeat excision specimens, HPV PCR/ISH, infectious workup, and targeted NGS) showed no invasive disease, no evidence of alternative infectious or melanocytic processes, and were HPV-negative, supporting a final diagnosis of multifocal HPV-negative squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease) of the penile shaft and left middle finger with no current histologic invasion and negative margins on excision.
steps.synthesis_prompt:
You are a medical diagnosis synthesizer. Based on all the information gathered during a clinical evaluation, provide a single, specific final diagnosis.

## Information Gathered:
- No clinical information or images provided yet; initiating diagnostic evaluation for dermatologic lesions.
- Vital signs: Temperature 36.8°C, Blood Pressure 130/85 mmHg, Heart Rate 82 bpm, Respiratory Rate 14/min — within normal limits, no fever or hemodynamic instability.
- 62-year-old man; red, crusty spots on penis and left middle finger first noticed four months ago (prior to arrival in US); lesions have increased slightly in size and crustiness; no bleeding, ulceration, pain, or pruritus.
- 62-year-old man with red, crusty spots on penis and left middle finger for ~4 months; lesions have gradually enlarged and become crustier but are non-bleeding, non-ulcerated, non-painful, non-pruritic. Prior treatments for syphilis and eczema in Africa were ineffective. No history of HIV or immunosuppression, no new medications, monogamous relationship.
- Erythematous plaques with areas of crusting, oozing, and irregular borders on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger; lesions are firm, non-tender, without warmth; no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.
- Biopsy from penile and left middle finger lesions shows cells with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitotic figures within follicle-bearing epithelium; HPV testing returned normal/negative.
- Deeper histopathology and immunohistochemistry (p16, cytokeratin AE1/AE3, Ki-67) returned 'NORMAL READINGS'.
- Additional immunohistochemistry panel (p63, CK5/6, CK7, EMA, CEA, S100) and explicit reporting of deeper-level sections (depth of invasion and margin status) returned normal/negative readings.
- Excisional biopsies of the penile and left middle finger lesions with extended immunohistochemistry panel (p40, p63, CK5/6, CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15, SOX10, Melan-A, S100, CD3, CD4) and HPV PCR returned 'NORMAL READINGS'.
- Expert dermatopathology review of all original biopsy and excision slides with repeat HPV testing (PCR and ISH) returned normal readings with no residual intraepidermal or invasive disease reported.
- Repeat punch biopsies including fungal/mycobacterial cultures, PAS/GMS and AFB stains, and PCR for Leishmania returned normal/negative results with no organisms identified and histopathology again non-diagnostic for invasion.

## Task:
Provide a single, specific diagnosis (1-3 words). Examples:
- "Acute appendicitis"
- "Community-acquired pneumonia"
- "Type 2 diabetes mellitus"

Diagnosis:
